sen.j: 岩倉具視（いわくらともみ、文政8年9月15日 (旧暦)（1825年10月26日）- 明治16年（1883年）7月20日）は日本の公家､政治家。
sen.e: Tomomi IWAKURA (October 26, 1825 - July 20, 1883) was a Japanese court noble and also a politician.
Tomomi IWAKURA (October 26, 1825 - July 20, 1883) was a Japanese court noble and a politician.
Tomomi IWAKURA (October 26, 1825 - July 20, 1883) was a Japanese court noble and a politician.

sen.j: 幼名は周丸（かねまる）、号は対岳。
sen.e: His childhood name was Kanemaru and his nickname was Taigaku.
His childhood name was Kanemaru and his nickname was Taigaku.
His childhood name was Kanemaru and his nickname was Taigaku.

sen.j: 謹慎中の法名は友山。
sen.e: His Buddhist name during his probation period was Yuzan.
His Buddhist name during this probation period was Yuzan.
His Buddhist name during this probation period was Yuzan.

sen.j: 正一位。
sen.e: His rank was Shoichii (Senior First Rank).
His rank was Shoichii (Senior First Rank).
His rank was Shoichii (Senior First Rank).

sen.j: 前権中納言堀河康親の次男として京都に生まれる。
sen.e: Tomomi IWAKURA was born in Kyoto as the second son of Yasuchika HORIKAWA who was formerly a gon-chunagon (provisional middle counselor).
Tomomi IWAKURA was born in Kyoto as the second son of Yasuchika HORIKAWA who was formerly a gon-chunagon (provisional middle counselor).
Tomomi IWAKURA was born in Kyoto as the second son of Yasuchika HORIKAWA who was formerly Gon Chunagon (a provisional vice-councilor of state).
sen.cmt: 「権中納言」→統一リストの表記に修正

sen.j: 天保9年（1838年）に岩倉具慶の養子となる。
sen.e: In 1838, he was adopted by Tomoyoshi IWAKURA.
In 1838, he was adopted by Tomoyoshi IWAKURA.
In 1838, he was adopted by Tomoyoshi IWAKURA.

sen.j: 当時の岩倉家は、家計逼迫し、屋敷を賭場にして、その寺銭で糊口をしのいでいた。
sen.e: The Iwakura family at the time was having a hard time making ends meet; therefore, they offered their own residence as a gambling house and barely lived on the rent.
The Iwakura family at the time was having a hard time making ends meet; therefore, they offered their own residence as a gambling house and barely lived on the rent.
The Iwakura family at the time was having a hard time making ends meet; therefore, they offered their own residence as a gambling house and barely lived on the rent.

sen.j: 関白・鷹司政通の門流となり、朝廷改革の意見書を提出した。
sen.e: He joined the sect led by the Kanpaku Masamichi TAKATSUKASA and submitted a report with his opinion about reform of the Imperial court.
He joined the sect led by the Kanpaku Masamichi TAKATSUKASA and submitted a report with his opinion about reform of the Imperial court.
He joined the sect led by the Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) Masamichi TAKATSUKASA and submitted a report with his opinion about reform of the Imperial court.

sen.j: 安政元年（1854年）に孝明天皇の侍従となる。
sen.e: In 1854, he became a jiju (chamberlain) of Emperor Komei.
In 1854, he became a jiju (chamberlain) of Emperor Komei.
In 1854, he became a jiju (chamberlain) of Emperor Komei.

sen.j: 安政5年（1858年）に老中・堀田正睦が日米修好通商条約の勅許を得るため上京した時に、反対派の公家を集めて阻止行動を起こした（いわゆる「廷臣八十八卿列参事件」）。
sen.e: In 1858, when the Roju Masayoshi HOTTA visited the capital to obtain a charter for signing the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan, Tomomi IWAKURA gathered Court nobles who were against the treaty and attempted to stop the signing of the treaty (so-called the 'Teishin hachiju-hachi kyo ressan jiken').

In 1858, when the Roju Masayoshi HOTTA visited the capital to obtain a charter for signing the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan, Tomomi IWAKURA gathered Court nobles who were against the treaty and attempted to stop the signing of the treaty (so-called the 'Teishin hachiju-hachi kyo ressan jiken').

In 1858, when the Roju (member of Shogun's council of elders) Masayoshi HOTTA visited the capital to obtain a charter for signing the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan, Tomomi IWAKURA gathered Court nobles who were against the treaty and attempted to stop the signing of the treaty (so-called the 'Teishin hachiju-hachi kyo ressan jiken' (Demo of eighty-eight retainers of Imperial Court)).
sen.cmt: Rojuの補足を追加、ローマ字表記"Teishin hachiju-hachi kyo ressan jiken"に英訳をつけました。

sen.j: 安政7年（1860年）に桜田門外の変で井伊直弼が暗殺された後、公武合体をすすめ和宮降嫁を推進した。
sen.e: After Naosuke II was assassinated in the Sakuaradamon-gai no hen (incident outside Sakurada gate) in 1860, he recommended kobu gattai (integration of the court and the shogunate) and marrying Kazunomiya off to someone outside the Imperial family.

After Naosuke II was assassinated in the 1860 Sakuaradamon-gai no hen (incident outside Sakurada gate), he recommended kobu gattai (integration of the court and the shogunate) and marrying Kazunomiya off to someone outside the Imperial family.

After Naosuke II was assassinated in the 1860 Sakuaradamon-gai no hen (incident outside Sakurada-mon Gate), he recommended kobu gattai (integration of the court and the shogunate) and marrying Kazunomiya off to someone outside the Imperial family.

sen.j: このため、尊王攘夷派の志士たちは岩倉を佐幕派として排斥しようと朝廷に圧力をかけた。
sen.e: This event made the supporters of the idea of reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners perceive Tomomi as being in the sabaku-sect (in support of the shogunate); therefore, they pressured the Imperial court to eliminate him.

This event made the supporters of the idea of reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners perceive Tomomi as being in the sabaku-sect (in support of the shogunate); therefore, they pressured the Imperial court to eliminate him.

This event made the supporters of the idea of reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners perceive Tomomi as being in the sabaku-sect (in support of the shogunate); therefore, they pressured the Imperial court to eliminate him.

sen.j: このため、文久2年（1862年）に京都市の霊源寺にて出家。
sen.e: As a result, Tomomi entered the priesthood at the Reigen-ji Temple in Kyoto City in 1862.
As a result, Tomomi entered the priesthood at the Reigen-ji Temple in Kyoto City in 1862.
As a result, Tomomi entered the priesthood at the Reigen-ji Temple in Kyoto City in 1862.

sen.j: 霊源寺、西芳寺を移り住み、京都洛北の岩倉村に幽居した。
sen.e: He lived at the Reigen-ji Temple and the Saiho-ji temple, and then led his retired life in the Iwakura-mura Village located in the Rakuhoku area in Kyoto.
He lived at the Reigen-ji Temple and the Saiho-ji temple, and then led his retired life in the Iwakura-mura Village located in the Rakuhoku area in Kyoto.
He lived at the Reigen-ji Temple and the Saiho-ji temple, and then led his retired life in the Iwakura-mura Village located in the Rakuhoku area in Kyoto.

sen.j: 幽居中も意見書を書いて朝廷や薩摩藩の同志に送るなどの活動を続けた。
sen.e: He continued his own activity even during his retired life by sending his reports to the Imperial court or his fellows of the Satsuma-han (domain).
He continued his own activity even during his retired life by sending his reports to the Imperial court or his fellows of the Satsuma-han (domain).
He continued his own activity even during his retired life by sending his reports to the Imperial court or his fellows of the Satsuma Domain.
sen.cmt: Satsuma-han (domain)→Satsuma clanとしました。(人の集団の扱いと解釈)

sen.j: この間に薩摩藩の動向に呼応する形で倒幕派へと路線を変更させた。
sen.e: By aligning himself with the Satsuma-han, he successfully made the han change their goal, which was to overthrow the shogunate.
By aligning himself with the Satsuma-han, he successfully made the han change their goal, which was to overthrow the shogunate.
By aligning himself with the Satsuma clan, he successfully made the han change their goal, which was to overthrow the shogunate.
sen.cmt: the Satsuma-han→the Satsuma clanとしました。

sen.j: 慶応2年（1866年）の徳川家茂の死を機会に朝廷の名において列藩召集を行なおうとするが失敗、孝明天皇の崩御の際には毒殺説が流れ、首謀者として疑われた（一説に自分が成り上がろうとして孝明天皇を暗殺し、幼く操縦しやすいと思われる明治天皇を早く即位させ利用した、という説もある）。
sen.e: In 1866, he tried to summon personnel of various domains in the name of the Imperial court when Iemochi TOKUGAWA died, but this attempt failed, and then, when Emperor Komei died, there was a rumor that he was poisoned and Tomomi was suspected of killing him (there has been a theory that Tomomi assassinated Emperor Komei in order to raise his own position so that he could make young and easily maneuverable Emperor Meiji take over the throne).

In 1866, he tried to summon personnel of various domains in the name of the Imperial court when Iemochi TOKUGAWA died, but this attempt failed. When Emperor Komei died, there was a rumor that he was poisoned and Tomomi was suspected of killing him (there has been a theory that Tomomi assassinated Emperor Komei in order to raise his own position so that he could make young and easily manipulable Emperor Meiji take over the throne).

In 1866, he tried to summon personnel of various domains in the name of the Imperial court when Iemochi TOKUGAWA died, but this attempt failed. When Emperor Komei died, there was a rumor that he was poisoned and Tomomi was suspected of killing him (there has been a theory that Tomomi assassinated Emperor Komei in order to raise his own position so that he could make young and easily manipulable Emperor Meiji take over the throne).

sen.j: 慶応3年12月9日（1868年1月3日）には王政復古 (日本)の大号令と徳川慶喜への辞官納地発令を実現し、天皇親政実現へのスタートを切った。
sen.e: On January 3, 1868, he issued the Declaration of Restoration of Imperial Rule and also issued an order to Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA to resign his government post and return his land to the Emperor, marking the first step toward realization of an emperor-ruled country.

On January 3, 1868, he issued the Declaration of Restoration of Imperial Rule and also issued an order to Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA to resign his government post, and return his land to the Emperor, marking the first step toward realization of an emperor-ruled country.

On January 3, 1868, he issued the Declaration of Restoration of Imperial Rule and also issued an order to Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA to resign his government post, and return his land to the Emperor, marking the first step toward realization of an emperor-ruled country.

sen.j: 明治維新後、岩倉は参与、議定、副総裁、輔相、大納言、外務卿、右大臣と昇任していった。
sen.e: After the Meiji ishin (Meiji Restoration), Iwakura continued to be promoted in the order of Sanyo (Councilor), Gi-jo (Decision Maker), Fuku-sosai (Vice-President of the new Meiji government), Ho-sho (Chief Administrative Officer), Dainagon (Chief of the Councilor of State), Gaimu-kyo (Chief Foreign Minister), and Udaijin (Great Minister of the Right).

After the Meiji ishin (Meiji Restoration), Iwakura continued to be promoted in the order of Sanyo (Councilor), Gi-jo (Decision Maker), Fuku-sosai (Vice-President of the new Meiji government), Ho-sho (Chief Administrative Officer), Dainagon (Chief of the Councilor of State), Gaimu-kyo (Chief Foreign Minister), and Udaijin (Great Minister of the Right).

After the Meiji Restoration, Iwakura continued to be promoted in the order of Sanyo (Councilor), Gijo (Decision Maker), Fuku-sosai (Vice-President of the new Meiji government), Ho-sho (Chief Administrative Officer), Dainagon (Chief Councilor of State), Gaimu-kyo (Chief Foreign Minister), and Udaijin (Minister of the Right).
sen.cmt: Meiji ishinを削除し、the Meiji Restorationのみとしました。Gi-jo→Gijoとし、Dainagon, Udaijin→統一リストの表記に修正

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年）には特命全権大使として、木戸孝允らを率いて岩倉使節団を組織し、欧米の文化・制度を視察した。
sen.e: In 1871, he as a Tokumei-zenken-taishi (extraordinary and plenipotentiary ambassador) established the Iwakura shisetsudan (Iwakura Mission) together with Takayoshi KIDO and others, and studied foreign cultures and systems.

In 1871, he established the Iwakura shisetsudan (Iwakura Mission) as a Tokumei-zenken-taishi (extraordinary and plenipotentiary ambassador) together with Takayoshi KIDO and others, and studied foreign cultures and systems.

In 1871, he established the Iwakura shisetsudan (Iwakura Mission) as a Tokumei-zenken-taishi (extraordinary and plenipotentiary ambassador) together with Takayoshi KIDO and others, and studied foreign cultures and systems.

sen.j: 帰国後は征韓論論争において、西郷隆盛を大使として朝鮮に派遣する案に反対して辞意を表明し、その後西郷の派遣を無期延期させた（その結果、西郷は参議・近衛都督を辞職した）。
sen.e: After returning to Japan, over the Seikan-ron (debate over conquering Korea), he opposed the idea of dispatching Takamori SAIGO to Korea as an ambassador and then postponed the dispatch indefinitely (as a result, Takamori resigned as Sangi (Royal Advisor) and Konoe-totoku (Commander-in-Chief of the Imperial Guard)).

After returning to Japan, over the Seikan-ron (debate over conquering Korea), he opposed the idea of dispatching Takamori SAIGO to Korea as an ambassador and then postponed the dispatch indefinitely (as a result, Takamori resigned as Sangi [Royal Advisor] and Konoe-totoku [Commander-in-Chief of the Imperial Guard]).

After returning to Japan, over the Seikan-ron (debate over conquering Korea), he opposed the idea of dispatching Takamori SAIGO to Korea as an ambassador and then postponed the dispatch indefinitely (as a result, Takamori resigned as Sangi (Royal Advisor) and Konoe-totoku (Commander-in-Chief of the Imperial Guard)).

sen.j: 明治7年（1874年）東京喰違坂附近で征韓論争の結果に不満を抱く高知県士族武市熊吉らに襲撃され、怪我を負う（喰違の変）。
sen.e: In 1874, near the Kuichigaizaka Hill in Tokyo, he was attacked by Kumakichi TAKECHI, a samurai descendent in Kochi Prefecture, and others who were not satisfied with the result of the Seikan-ron debate and was injured (the Kuichigai Incident).

In 1874, near the Kuichigaizaka Hill in Tokyo, he was attacked by Kumakichi TAKECHI, a samurai descendent in Kochi Prefecture, and others who were not satisfied with the result of the Seikan-ron debate and was injured (the Kuichigai Incident).

In 1874, near the Kuichigaizaka Hill in Tokyo, he was attacked by Kumakichi TAKECHI, a samurai descendent in Kochi Prefecture, and others who were not satisfied with the result of the Seikan-ron debate and was injured (the Kuichigai Incident).

sen.j: 立憲問題では初めは制定に反対であったが、自由民権運動の高まりや井上毅の具申を受けて方針をかえ、大日本帝国憲法の制定に向けて尽力した。
sen.e: Although he originally opposed the idea of establishment of a constitution, he changed his policy in response to the growing movement for civic rights and freedom and also to the opinion of Kowashi INOUE, and devoted himself to establishment of the Dainipponteikoku Kenpo (Meiji Constitution).

Although he originally opposed the idea of a constitution, he changed his policy in response to the growing movement for civic rights and freedom and also to the opinion of Kowashi INOUE. He also devoted himself to the establishment of the Dainipponteikoku Kenpo (Meiji Constitution).

Although he originally opposed the idea of a constitution, he changed his policy in response to the growing movement for civic rights and freedom and also to the opinion of Kowashi INOUE. He also devoted himself to the establishment of the Constitution of the Empire of Japan.
sen.cmt: the Dainipponteikoku Kenpo (Meiji Constitution)→the Constitution of the Empire of Japan としました。

sen.j: 明治14年（1881年）には急進路線を採る大隈重信と対立。
sen.e: In 1881 he disagreed with Shigenobu OKUMA who was a radicalist.
In 1881, he disagreed with Shigenobu OKUMA who was a radical.
In 1881, he disagreed with Shigenobu OKUMA who was a radical.

sen.j: 漸進路線の伊藤博文らと組んで大隈を政府から放逐する（明治十四年の政変）。
sen.e: He allied with the moderate Hirobumi ITO to expel Shigenobu OKUMA from the government (Meiji juyonen no seihen (the failed Meiji-14 coup of 1881)).
He allied with the moderate Hirobumi ITO to expel Shigenobu OKUMA from the government (Meiji juyonen no seihen [the failed Meiji-14 coup of 1881]).
He allied with the moderate Hirobumi ITO to expel Shigenobu OKUMA from the government (The Failed Meiji-14 Coup of 1881).
sen.cmt: Meiji juyonen no seihenを削除し、"The Failed Meiji-14 Coup of 1881"としました。

sen.j: その後、皇室財産の確立と華族保護につとめ、霞会館・学習院・日本鉄道会社の設立にも関与した。
sen.e: Then he devoted himself to reservation of Imperial family assets and protection of the new peerage, and also, he was involved in establishment of Kasumi-kaikan, Gakushuin school, and Nippon Railway.
Then he devoted himself to reservation of Imperial family assets and protection of the new peerage, and also, he was involved in establishment of Kasumi-kaikan, Gakushuin school, and Nippon Railway.
Then he devoted himself to reservation of Imperial family assets and protection of the new peerage, and also, he was involved in establishment of Kasumi-kaikan, Gakushuin school, and Nippon Railway.

sen.j: エルヴィン・フォン・ベルツによって癌の告知を受ける。
sen.e: He was informed that he had cancer by Erwin von Bälz.
He was informed that he had cancer by Erwin von Bälz.
He was informed that he had cancer by Erwin von BAELZ.

sen.j: 岩倉は史上初めて「癌告知」を受けた日本人となった。
sen.e: Tomomi IWAKURA was the first Japanese who was 'informed' that he had cancer.
Tomomi IWAKURA was the first Japanese who was 'informed' that he had cancer.
Tomomi IWAKURA was the first Japanese who was 'informed' that he had cancer.

sen.j: 明治16年（1883年）に咽頭で死去、享年59。
sen.e: In 1883, when he was 59 years old, he died of throat cancer.
sen.cmt: 「咽頭で死去」→「咽頭癌で死去」と解釈し、そのように訳出しました。
sen.e: In 1883, when he was 59 years old, he died of throat cancer.
In 1883, when he was 59 years old, he died of throat cancer.

sen.j: 国葬が執り行われた。
sen.e: A state funeral was held for him.
A state funeral was held for him.
A state funeral was held for him.

sen.j: 墓所は東京都品川区の海晏寺。
sen.e: His grave is at the Kaian-ji Temple in Shinagawa Ward, Tokyo.
His grave is at the Kaian-ji Temple in Shinagawa Ward, Tokyo.
His grave is at the Kaian-ji Temple in Shinagawa Ward, Tokyo.

tit.cmt: 経歴と同義と解釈しました。

sen.j: ※日付は明治4年までは旧暦。
sen.e: *Dates are based on the lunar calendar up to 1871.
*Dates are based on the lunar calendar up to 1871.
*Dates are based on the lunar calendar up to 1871.
In the year 1838:
In the year 1838:
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正

sen.j: 10月28日 (旧暦)、従五位下叙位。
sen.e: On October 28 (by the lunar calendar), he was appointed to the Jugoige rank (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).
On October 28 (by the lunar calendar), he was appointed to the Jugoige rank (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).
December 14: He was appointed to the Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正、Jugoinogeとし、rank削除October 28 (by the lunar calendar):→December 14に変更しました。

sen.j: 12月11日 (旧暦)、元服し、昇殿を許される。
sen.e: On December 11 (by the lunar calendar), he came to the age of maturity and was permitted to enter the Tenjo-no-ma room in Seiryo-den.
On December 11 (by the lunar calendar), he came to the age of maturity and was permitted to enter the Tenjo-no-ma room in Seiryo-den.
January 25, 1839 (December 11, 1838 in old lunar calendar): He came to the age of maturity and was permitted to enter the Tenjo no ma room in Seiryo-den.
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正、ハイフンをとりTenjo no ma roomとしました。December 11 (by the lunar calendar)→January 25, 1839 (December 11, 1838 in old lunar calendar)に変更しました。

sen.j: 天保12年（1841年）6月4日 (旧暦)、従五位上昇叙。
sen.e: On June 4, 1841 (by the lunar calendar), he was promoted to the Jugoijo rank (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade).
On June 4, 1841 (by the lunar calendar), he was promoted to the Jugoijo rank (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade).
July 21, 1841: He was promoted to the Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade).
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正、Jugoinojoとし、rank削除 June 4, 1841 (by the lunar calendar)→July 21 に変更しました。

sen.j: 弘化2年（1845年）2月18日 (旧暦)、正五位下昇叙。
sen.e: On February 18, 1845 (by the lunar calendar), he was promoted to the Shogoige rank (Senior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).
On February 18, 1845 (by the lunar calendar), he was promoted to the Shogoige rank (Senior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).
February 18, 1845: He was promoted to the Shogoinoge (Senior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正、Shogoinogeとし、rank削除February 18, 1845 (by the lunar calendar)→March 25に変更しました。

sen.e: In the year 1854:
sen.cmt: 「嘉永7年1854年）」→西暦前の開きかっこを追加し、「嘉永7年(1854年)」として訳出しました。
sen.e: In the year 1854:
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正

sen.j: 3月20日 (旧暦)、侍従任官。
sen.e: On March 20 (by the lunar calendar), he was appointed to Jiju.
On March 20 (by the lunar calendar), he was appointed to Jiju.
April 17: He was appointed to Jiju.
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正March 20 (by the lunar calendar)→April 17に変更しました。

sen.j: 6月10日 (旧暦)、従四位下昇叙し、侍従元の如し。
sen.e: On June 10 (by the lunar calendar), he was promoted to the Jushiige rank (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) while being concurrently appointed to Jiju.
On June 10 (by the lunar calendar), he was promoted to the Jushiige rank (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) while being concurrently appointed to Jiju.
July 4: He was promoted to the Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) while being concurrently appointed to Jiju.
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正、Jushiinogeとし、rank削除June 10 (by the lunar calendar)→July 4に変更しました。

sen.j: 万延元年（1860年）12月29日 (旧暦)、右近衛権少将に転任。
sen.e: On December 29, 1860 (by the lunar calendar), he was reassigned as Ukonoegonshosho (Temporary Minor Captain of Imperial Guard of the Right).
On December 29, 1860 (by the lunar calendar), he was reassigned as Ukonoegonshosho (Temporary Minor Captain of Imperial Guard of the Right).
February 8, 1861: He was reassigned as Ukone no Gon no shosho (Provisional Minor Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards).
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正、「右近衛権少将」の表記を変更December 29, 1860 (by the lunar calendar)→February 8, 1861に変更しました。

sen.j: 万延2年（1861年）1月5日 (旧暦)、正四位下昇叙し、右近衛権少将元の如し。
sen.e: On January 5, 1861 (by the lunar calendar), he was promoted to the Shoshiinoge rank (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) while being concurrently appointed to Ukonoegonshosho.
On January 5, 1861 (by the lunar calendar), he was promoted to the Shoshiinoge rank (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) while being concurrently appointed to Ukonoegonshosho.
February 14, 1861: He was promoted to the Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) while being concurrently appointed to Ukonoegonshosho.
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正、rank削除January 5, 1861 (by the lunar calendar)→February 14, 1861 に変更しました。

sen.e: In the year 1862:
In the year 1862:
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正

sen.j: 5月15日 (旧暦)、左近衛権中将に転任。
sen.e: On May 15 (by the lunar calendar), he was reassigned as Sakonoegonchujo (Temporary Deputy General of Imperial Guard of the Left).
On May 15 (by the lunar calendar), he was reassigned as Sakonoegonchujo (Temporary Deputy General of Imperial Guard of the Left).
June 12: He was reassigned as Sakone gon no chujo (Provisional Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards).
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正、「左近衛権中将」の表記を変更May 15 (by the lunar calendar)→June 12に変更しました。

sen.j: 8月20日 (旧暦)、左近衛権中将辞任し、蟄居。
sen.e: On August 20 (by the lunar calendar), he resigned as Sakonoegonchujo and started a life in retirement.
On August 20 (by the lunar calendar), he resigned as Sakonoegonchujo and started his retirement life.
September 13: He resigned as Sakone gon no chujo and started his retirement life.
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正、Sakone gon no chujoとしました。August 20 (by the lunar calendar)→September 13に変更しました。

sen.j: 8月22日 (旧暦)、落餝。
sen.e: On August 22 (by the lunar calendar), he entered the priesthood.
On August 22 (by the lunar calendar), he entered the priesthood.
September 15: He entered the priesthood.
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正August 22 (by the lunar calendar)→September 15に変更しました。

sen.j: 法名：友山
sen.e: Buddhist name: Yuzan
Buddhist name: Yuzan
Buddhist name: Yuzan
In the year 1867:
In the year 1867:

sen.j: 12月9日 (旧暦)、明治政府参与兼務。
sen.e: On December 9 (by the lunar calendar), he was also appointed to Sanyo of the Meiji government.
On December 9 (by the lunar calendar), he was also appointed to Sanyo of the Meiji government.

sen.j: 12月27日 (旧暦)、明治政府参与から議定に異動兼務。
sen.e: On December 27 (by the lunar calendar), he was reassigned as Gijo while still being Sanyo of the Meiji government.
On December 27 (by the lunar calendar), he was reassigned as Gijo while still being Sanyo of the Meiji government.
January 21, 1868 (December 27, 1867 in old lunar calendar): He was reassigned as Gijo while still being Sanyo of the Meiji government.

In the year 1868:

sen.j: 1月9日 (旧暦)、明治政府（以下、この年のみ政府と略し表記）副総裁兼任。
sen.e: On January 9 (by the lunar calendar), he was additionally appointed to Vice President of the Meiji government (written as "the Government" only for this year).
On January 9 (by the lunar calendar), he was additionally appointed to Vice President of the Meiji government (written as 'the Government' only for this year).
February 2: He was additionally appointed to Vice President of the Meiji government (written as 'the Government' only for this year).

sen.j: 1月27日 (旧暦)、政府会計事務総督及び海陸軍事務総督兼務。
sen.e: On January 27 (by the lunar calendar), he was additionally appointed to Seifu-kaikei-jimu-sotoku (General Manager of Government Accounting) and Kairikugun-jimu-sotoku (General Manager of Navy and Army Affairs).

On January 27 (by the lunar calendar), he was additionally appointed to Seifu-kaikei-jimu-sotoku (General Manager of Government Accounting) and Kairikugun-jimu-sotoku (General Manager of Navy and Army Affairs).
February 20: He was additionally appointed to Seifu-kaikei-jimu-sotoku (General Manager of Government Accounting) and Kairikugun-jimu-sotoku (General Manager of Navy and Army Affairs).
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正January 27 (by the lunar calendar)→February 20に変更しました。

sen.j: 2月2日 (旧暦)、従三位昇叙し、右兵衛督に任官（時に、政府副総裁議定会計事務総督海陸軍事務総督従三位行右兵衛督）。
sen.e: On February 2 (by the lunar calendar), he was promoted to the Jusanmi rank (Junior Third Rank) and appointed to U-hyoe-no-kami (Captain of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards) (at the time, he was the Vice President, Gijo, Seifu-kaikei-jimu-sotoku, and Kairikugun-jimu-sotoku of the Government, at the Jusanmi rank, and was the U-hyoe-no-kami).

On February 2 (by the lunar calendar), he was promoted to the Jusanmi rank (Junior Third Rank) and appointed to U-hyoe-no-kami (Captain of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards) (at the time, he was the Vice President, Gijo, Seifu-kaikei-jimu-sotoku, and Kairikugun-jimu-sotoku of the Government, at the Jusanmi rank, and was the U-hyoe-no-kami).

February 24: He was promoted to the Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) and appointed to Uhyoe no kami (Captain of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards) (at the time, he was the Vice President, Gijo, Seifu-kaikei-jimu-sotoku, and Kairikugun-jimu-sotoku of the Government, at the Jusanmi rank, and was the Uhyoe no kami).
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正、Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank)、Uhyoe no kamiとしました。February 2 (by the lunar calendar)→February 24に変更しました。

sen.j: 2月20日 (旧暦)、政府会計事務総督及び海陸軍事務総督辞職。
sen.e: On February 20 (by the lunar calendar), he resigned as Seifu-kaikei-jimu-sotoku and Kairikugun-jimu-sotoku.

March 13: He resigned as Seifu-kaikei-jimu-sotoku and Kairikugun-jimu-sotoku.
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正February 20 (by the lunar calendar)→March 13に変更しました。

sen.j: 閏4月20日 (旧暦)、政府副総裁辞職。
sen.e: On April 20 (leap date, by the lunar calendar), he resigned as Vice President of the Government.
On April 20 (leap date, by the lunar calendar), he resigned as Vice President of the Government.
June 10: He resigned as Vice President of the Government.
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正April 20 (leap date, by the lunar calendar)→June 10に変更しました。

sen.j: 閏4月21日 (旧暦)、政府制度改正により、議政官たる上局議定及び輔相兼務。
sen.e: On April 21 (leap date, by the lunar calendar), after the government system changed, he was appointed both to Jyokyoku-gi-jo of Gisei-kan (upper decision maker at the lawmaking organ) and Ho-sho.
On April 21 (leap date, by the lunar calendar), after the government system changed, he was appointed both to Jyokyoku-gi-jo of Gisei-kan (upper decision maker at the lawmaking organ) and Ho-sho.
June 11: After the government system changed, he was appointed both to Jokyoku Gijo of Gisei-kan (upper decision maker at the lawmaking organ) and Ho-sho.
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正、Jyokyoku-gi-jo→Jokyoku Gijoとしました。April 21 (leap date, by the lunar calendar)→June 11に変更しました。

sen.e: In the year 1869:
In the year 1869:
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正

sen.j: 1月7日 (旧暦)、輔相辞職。
sen.e: On January 7 (by the lunar calendar), he resigned as Ho-sho.
On January 7 (by the lunar calendar), he resigned as Ho-sho.
February 17: He resigned as Ho-sho.
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正January 7 (by the lunar calendar)→February 17に変更しました。

sen.j: 1月25日 (旧暦)、正二位に昇叙し、権大納言に転任。
sen.e: On January 25 (by the lunar calendar), he was promoted to the Shonii rank (Senior Second Rank) and was reassigned as Gon-dainagon (Junior Chief of the Councilor of State).
On January 25 (by the lunar calendar), he was promoted to the Shonii rank (Senior Second Rank) and was reassigned as Gon-dainagon (Junior Chief of the Councilor of State).
March 7: He was promoted to the Shonii (Senior Second Rank) and was reassigned as Gon Dainagon (a provisional chief councilor of state).

sen.j: 上局議定元の如し。
sen.e: He was concurrently Jyokyoku-gi-jo.
He was concurrently Jyokyoku-gi-jo.
He retained his position as Jokyoku Gijo.
sen.cmt: Jokyoku Gijoとし、文章を修正しました。

sen.j: 7月8日 (旧暦)、制度改正により、上局議定より大納言に異動。
sen.e: On July 8 (by the lunar calendar), due to the revision of the system, he was reassigned from Jyokyoku-gi-jo to Dai-nagon (Chief of the Councilor of State).
On July 8 (by the lunar calendar), due to the revision of the system, he was reassigned from Jyokyoku-gi-jo to Dai-nagon (Chief of the Councilor of State).
August 15: Due to the revision of the system, he was reassigned from Jokyoku Gijo to Dainagon.

sen.j: 11月23日 (旧暦)、兵部省御用掛兼務。
sen.e: On November 23 (by the lunar calendar), he was additionally appointed to Goyo-gakari of Hyobu-sho (Ministry of Military).
On November 23 (by the lunar calendar), he was additionally appointed to Goyo-gakari of Hyobu-sho (Ministry of Military).
November 23 (by the lunar calendar): He was additionally appointed to Goyo-gakari of Hyobu-sho (Ministry of Military).

sen.j: 7月14日 (旧暦)、制度改正により大納言から外務卿に異動。
sen.e: On July 14 (by the lunar calendar), due to the revision of the system, he was reassigned from Dai-nagon to Gaimu-kyo.
On July 14 (by the lunar calendar), due to the revision of the system, he was reassigned from Dai-nagon to Gaimu-kyo.
August 29: Due to the revision of the system, he was reassigned from Dainagon to Gaimu-kyo.

sen.j: 10月8日 (旧暦)、右大臣並びに遣外使節団特命全権大使に異動。
sen.e: On October 8 (by the lunar calendar), he was reassigned as the Udaijin and Kengai-shisetsudan-tokumei-zenken-taishi (extraordinary and plenipotentiary ambassador of the overseas mission).
On October 8 (by the lunar calendar), he was reassigned as the Udaijin and Kengai-shisetsudan-tokumei-zenken-taishi (extraordinary and plenipotentiary ambassador of the overseas mission).

November 12 (by the lunar calendar) the ship carrying the mission left Yokohama.
December 23: The ship carrying the mission left Yokohama.

On September 13, the ship returned to Yokohama.
September 13: The ship returned to Yokohama.

sen.j: 10月20日、太政大臣代理兼任。
sen.e: On October 20, he was additionally appointed to the Deputy Dajo-daijin (Chancellor of the Realm).
On October 20, he was additionally appointed to the Deputy Dajo-daijin (Chancellor of the Realm).
October 20: He was additionally appointed to the Deputy Dajo-daijin (Grand minister of state).

sen.j: 但し、同日のみ。

This assignment was effective only on that day.
This assignment was effective only on that day.

sen.j: 4月19日、華族会館長兼帯。
sen.e: On April 19, he as additionally appointed to the President of Kazoku-kaikan.
On April 19, he as additionally appointed to the President of Kazoku-kaikan.
April 19: He as additionally appointed to the President of Kazoku-kaikan.

sen.j: 5月18日、従一位昇叙。

sen.j: 5月26日、華族督部長兼務。

On May 26, he was additionally appointed to the Head of the Kazoku-toku-bucho (Head of the Kazoku Management Department).

sen.j: 12月29日、勲一等旭日大綬章授章。
sen.e: On December 29, he received the Kun-itto-kyokujitsu-daijusho (the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun).
On December 29, he received the Kun-itto-kyokujitsu-daijusho (the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun).

sen.j: 11月1日、大勲位菊花大綬章授章。
sen.e: On November 1, he received the Daikuni-kikka-daijusho (the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum).
On November 1, he received the Daikuni-kikka-daijusho (the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum).

sen.e: On November 15, he resigned as the Kazoku-toku-bucho because of abolishment of the post.
On November 15, he was resigned as the Kazoku-toku-bucho because of the abolishment of the post.

sen.e: On April 7, he was additionally appointed to Kunai-sho-hensan-kyoku-sosai-kokoroe (Acting President of the Editorial Office of the Imperial Household Ministry).

sen.e: On July 23, he was raised to Grand Minister after his death.
On July 23, he was raised to Grand Minister after his death.
July 23: He was raised to Dajo-daijin after his death.

sen.e: On July 25, a state funeral was held.
On July 25, a state funeral was held.
July 25: A state funeral was held.

sen.j: 明治18年（1885年）7月20日、贈正一位。
sen.e: On July 20, 1885, he was raised to the Shoichii rank (Senior First Rank) as a posthumous honor.
On July 20, 1885, he was raised to the Shoichii rank (Senior First Rank) as a posthumous honor.

sen.j: 京都・洛北の実相院近くにあり、今は住宅に囲まれている。
sen.e: It was near the Jisso-in Temple in the Rakuhoku area in Kyoto, and it is now surrounded by houses.
It was near the Jisso-in Temple in the Rakuhoku area in Kyoto, and it is now surrounded by houses.
It was near the Jisso-in Temple in the Rakuhoku area in Kyoto, and it is now surrounded by houses.

sen.j: 数えの38歳で辞官・落飾した岩倉具視は地元の大工から古家を譲り受け、5年余り住んだ。
sen.e: Removing himself from the government post and entering the priesthood at the age of 38, Tomomi IWAKURA was given an old house from a local carpenter and lived there for over 5 years.
Removing himself from the government post and entering the priesthood at the age of 38, Tomomi IWAKURA was given an old house from a local carpenter and lived there for over 5 years.
Removing himself from the government post and entering the priesthood at the age of 38, Tomomi IWAKURA was given an old house from a local carpenter and lived there for over five years.

sen.j: 建物は質素な平屋建て二棟で、うち一棟は移住後増築したもの。
sen.e: He had two one-storied simple houses, and one of them was added after he moved into the original one.
He had two one-storied simple houses, and one of them was added after he moved into the original one.
He had two one-story simple houses, and one of them was added after he moved into the original one.

sen.j: 後に屋根の一部が茅葺きから瓦葺きに改築されたがほぼ当時のまま残されている。
sen.e: The roofs have been partly changed from thatched roofs to tiled roofs, but most of them still exist as they originally were.
The roofs have been partly changed from thatched roofs to tiled roofs, but most of them still exist as they originally were.
The roofs have been partly changed from thatched roofs to tiled roofs, but most of them still exist as they originally were.

sen.j: 幽居中とはいえ活発に政治活動を続けた具視はここでも浪士らにつけねらわれた。
sen.e: Although leading a retired life, Tomomi was still politically active and was therefore followed and targeted by warriors.
Although leading a retired life, Tomomi was still politically active and was therefore followed and targeted by warriors.
Although leading a retired life, Tomomi was still politically active and was therefore followed and targeted by warriors.

sen.j: 敷地内には「対岳文庫」と名付けられた小さな博物館があり、遺品が陳列されている。
sen.e: On his property there is a small museum called 'Taigaku-bunko' and his personal articles are displayed.
On his property there is a small museum called 'Taigaku-bunko' and his personal articles are on display.
On his property there is a small museum called 'Taigaku-bunko' and his personal articles are on display.

sen.j: 昭和26年（1951年）発行開始の日本銀行券B五百円券、および昭和44年（1969年）発行開始のC五百円券に岩倉の肖像が採用された。
sen.e: A portrait of Tomomi IWAKURA was used on 500 yen Japanese banknotes that started to circulate in 1951 (B) and also on 500 yen notes that started to circulate in 1969 (C).
A portrait of Tomomi IWAKURA was used on 500 Yen Japanese banknotes that began circulation in 1951 (B) and also on 500 Yen notes that began circulation in 1969 (C).
A portrait of Tomomi IWAKURA was used on 500 Yen Japanese banknotes that began circulation in 1951 (B) and also on 500 Yen notes that began circulation in 1969 (C).

sen.j: C五百円券は500円硬貨の登場（昭和57年（1982年））後も、昭和60年（1985年）まで製造されていた。
sen.e: The 500 yen note (C) was manufactured until 1985 even after 500 yen coins started to circulate in 1982.
The 500 Yen note (C) was manufactured until 1985 even after 500 Yen coins began circulation in 1982.
The 500 Yen note (C) was manufactured until 1985 even after 500 Yen coins began circulation in 1982.
